author: @sampzuckerman
text: The main difference with templates and string concatenation is that you can have if-then statements and for-loops in templates. If you want to use those with just string replacement, it's pretty difficult and gets unwieldy very quickly.

text: hi great video, thanks.  i have a strange problem.  When i say no to any news i still get the same news message as when i say yes, so i guess something is wrong with my intent code, i checked it many times....any ideas?  thanks.. from flask import Flask from flask_ask import Ask, statement, question, session  import json import requests import time #import unidecode  app = Flask(__name__) ask = Ask(app, "/")  def get_headlines():     pass  @app.route('/')  def homepage():     return "hello there" @ask.launch def start_skill():     welcome_message = 'hello would you like to hear some news?'     return question(welcome_message)  @ask.intent("YesIntent") def share_headlines():     headlines = get_headlines()     headlines_msg = 'The news is {}'.format(headlines)     return statement(headlines_msg)  @ask.intent("NoIntent") def no_intent():     bye_text = 'ok no news for you today. bye bye'     return statement(bye_text)   if __name__ == '__main__':     app.run(debug=True)

author: @jayache800
text: "Why use templating?" Because it allows you to abstract your business code from the speech text. Sure, you won't have <html> and <body>, etc, but it may come in handy to say Hello, {{name.first}} instead of concatenating strings in your Python business code. With complex speech sentences/paragraphs combining multiple variables, templates will be easier as you can decide which template to use in your business code and pass the appropriate data to the appropriate template based on those decisions. For small speech statements, templates may be more complex than otherwise.
